I'm not doing x, y, and z. Remember what Ephesians 4 dealt with. Remember what we see about complaining. God was not pleased. I mean, surely God's not pleased with someone that murders, but he's not pleased with someone that complains either. And this evening, we must have this reset, if you will, in our minds with regard to sin. Lead me into the way everlasting. And we'd come to that place where we say, listen, there's no unconfessed sin in my life. You're never going to reach a place of sinless perfection. There were preachers of yesteryear that taught it. I believe that it's wholly inaccurate from what you read in God's word. For God says in 1 John very plainly that if we say that we have no sin, that the truth is not in us, that we make him a liar. But when we sin, we have an advocate with the Father, Jesus Christ, the righteous. And so we understand we're not going to ever become sinless. But the reality is that we should be sinning less and less as we walk closer and closer with God. And we should have, and I'll use this term, and I don't mean to use it inappropriately, but we should have a short sin account with God. What do I mean by that? Well, the Holy Spirit, we should be walking in such communion with God, abiding with him, that when we sin, the Holy Spirit of God convicts us and we immediately confess that and forsake that and get that right and have that forgiveness and have that restoration, that restored fellowship and that joy. See, this evening, this table that is before us is a wonderful, wonderful table. The Lord's Supper reminds us of what Jesus did for us so that we could be saved.
